Award.AwardTitle: The Behavioral Economics of Job Search During Unemployment: New Field Evidence on Search and Psychological Frictions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program and is supported by the Economics program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Saurabh Bhargava at Carnegie Mellon University, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist studying job search behavior. Specifically, the present research explores the psychological factors that influence job search during unemployment. Many people find the experience of searching for work unpleasant and discouraging. The proposed research aims to test these assumptions and to provide new insights on the psychological mechanisms that might hinder the best possible job-search behaviors. These insights can directly inform the types of policies used to improve search behavior and speed up the pace at which job-seekers find suitable employment.

This project aims to contribute to economists' understanding of job search behavior by testing basic assumptions about the optimality of search effort and strategy and the assumed irrelevance of psychological factors such as discouragement. One reason that behavioral insights have been slow to affect labor economics is the difficulty of capturing labor market dynamics realistically in the laboratory. This research will address this gap by leveraging access to real-world data on the online job search behavior of several hundred thousand job seekers, and a field experiment with unemployed job seekers. Collectively, this will provide new evidence on (i) how individuals search, including effort and search wages, (ii) the optimality of such search relative to a benchmark of the standard model, and (iii) the psychological consequences of unemployment and their effect on search. Further, it will test psychologically informed interventions intended to improve job outcomes. Evidence on whether unemployed job seekers search suboptimally for work and, if so, what specific interventions can improve search will have implications for how economic theory should model job search decisions and unemployment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Previous research shows that long periods of unemployment are strongly associated with enduring damage to financial, physical, and mental health for affected households. These findings suggest that policies that help households speed exits from unemployment have the potential to dramatically improve welfare.

Policymakers rely on economic models to accurately predict how different policy levers will influence job search behavior and resulting employment. Recent advances in behavioral economics strongly suggest that incorporating psychologically-informed departures from traditional economic models improves our ability to predict such responses. Thus, clarifying the economic and psychological factors that drive job search has the potential to inform more effective policies and ultimately improve welfare.

A challenge for researchers studying job search is that the main factors theorized to influence job finding -- job search effort and reservation wages -- are seldom observed. Hence, the existing empirical literature on this topic typically infers individual decisions about job search from unemployment exits. The research supported by this grant was designed to study the factors influencing job search during unemployment using direct measures of job search decisions and behavior. This project involved analyzing archival data tracking search activity on a large online job search website and collecting new survey and behavioral data on job search effort and reservation wages, as well as survey measures of economically-relevant beliefs and psychological experiences of search not traditionally considered by economists.

To gain greater insights into job search behavior, we conduct three studies: an econometric analysis of search activity during a three-month period on a large job search website, a survey administered to three distinct samples of unemployed job seekers recruited through different online procedures to increase generalizability, and a six-week longitudinal study involving brief daily surveys and web-based tracking of job application progress and online job search activity. Our data revealed several striking patterns. One pattern observed across survey samples is that a substantial share of job seekers (over 20%) characterize their search effort as less than what they think it should be. Such reports are not consistent with standard economic models but could be accommodated by behavioral departures allowing the realistic possibility that people struggle to do unpleasant work, even when they've decided that they should do it.

Typical economic analyses do not account for the possibility that psychological factors like discouragement and diminished self-esteem may influence search effort and strategy. We find evidence suggesting that these seemingly non-economic factors do affect search behavior. Specifically, using survey measures of hedonic utility associated with job search, we show that more negative hedonic experiences predict lower search effort both between individuals and within individuals over the course of an unemployment spell.

We are currently preparing two manuscripts for submission to peer-reviewed publications. To date, we have presented our findings at the Annual Meeting of the Society of Judgment & Decision Making and shared findings and lessons for practitioners at organizations providing workforce services. The PI received postdoctoral training and opportunities for professional development with faculty at the sponsoring institution. One pre-doctoral student and one graduate student also received training in conducting field research in economics and received opportunities for professional development.
